item.title: Covid-19 linked to rise in chronic fatigue cases, new study reveals - India Today
item.description:
Covid-19 Linked to Rise in Chronic Fatigue Cases, New Study Reveals

Published On: Jan 17, 2025 | Source: Journal of General Internal Medicine

A recent study has found a significant rise in chronic fatigue syndrome cases among individuals recovering from Covid-19.

  • The study, funded by the US government, links long Covid to increased cases of myalgic encephalomyelitis/chronic fatigue syndrome (ME/CFS).
  • 4.5% of Covid-19 survivors met the diagnostic criteria for ME/CFS, compared to 0.6% of those uninfected.
  • The NIH conducted the study as part of its RECOVER initiative, analyzing data from 13,224 participants.
  • New ME/CFS cases post-Covid were found to be 15 times higher than pre-pandemic levels.
  • The identified symptoms included post-exertional malaise, orthostatic intolerance, and cognitive impairment.
  • The findings underline the necessity to understand Covid-19's role in triggering chronic conditions.
“These findings add to the growing evidence that infections like Covid-19 can lead to chronic fatigue syndrome.” - Dr. Suzanne D. Vernon

Understanding the triggers of ME/CFS may pave the way for improved treatments for chronic conditions associated with infections.

item.title: Experts bat for early detection to prevent hepatitis deaths - The Hindu
item.description:
Experts Advocate for Early Detection to Prevent Hepatitis Deaths

Published Date: January 17, 2025 Source: The Hindu

A two-day summit in Chennai focused on eliminating hepatitis emphasized the need for early detection to prevent deaths related to the viral infection.

  • The summit highlighted that 70% of hepatitis deaths are preventable.
  • Approximately 1.3 million people died of viral hepatitis globally in 2022, up from 1.1 million in 2019.
  • Experts call for increased awareness and improved treatment access in India.
  • An app for data collection and follow-up of hepatitis cases was launched during the summit.
  • Online courses for healthcare professionals were introduced to enhance skills in combating hepatitis.
“Hepatitis is a global crisis,” stated Rachel Holford, president of the World Hepatitis Alliance.

The summit reinforced the need for heightened awareness and proactive measures to control hepatitis, as well as the development of vaccines and treatment strategies to eliminate the disease.

item.title: Brain neurons that respond to sugar and fat offer new insights into obesity control - News-Medical.Net
item.description:
Brain Neurons That Respond to Sugar and Fat Offer New Insights into Obesity Control

Date: 2025-01-17 | Source: Nature Metabolism

In a recent study published in Nature Metabolism, researchers have discovered distinct neuronal populations in the hippocampus that are responsive to sugars and fats, providing new insights into mechanisms that could potentially combat obesity.

  • The hippocampus (HPC) is critical for forming memories associated with food and regulating intake.
  • Distinct neuronal populations activate in response to sugar or fat intake, with implications for dietary choices.
  • Ablating sugar-responsive neurons resulted in a significant decrease in sugar intake, while fat-responsive neuron ablation reduced fat intake.
  • The findings suggest that different populations of neurons in the HPC differentially influence nutritional memory and motivation.
“The findings illustrate the critical role of the dHPC in food intake control.”

This research highlights potential therapeutic targets within specific neuronal populations of the HPC to address obesity and related disorders.

item.title: Xenon Gas May Protect Against Alzheimer’s Disease in Animal Models - Technology Networks
item.description:
Xenon Gas May Protect Against Alzheimer’s Disease in Animal Models

Publication Date: October 2023 Source: Technology Networks

Recent research has indicated that inhaling Xenon gas can provide neuroprotective effects in mouse models of Alzheimer’s disease by reducing neuroinflammation and brain atrophy. A clinical trial is set to begin in early 2025.

  • Xenon gas inhalation suppressed neuroinflammation in Alzheimer’s disease models.
  • It increased protective neuronal states and enhanced microglial responses.
  • A phase 1 clinical trial will start in early 2025 with healthy volunteers.
  • The study reveals that Xenon can penetrate the blood-brain barrier, a significant barrier for treatments.
  • Potential future applications include treatments for multiple sclerosis and amyotrophic lateral sclerosis.
“If the clinical trial goes well, the opportunities for the use of Xenon gas are great. It could open the door to new treatments for helping patients with neurologic diseases.” - Howard Weiner, MD

This groundbreaking study suggests that Xenon gas could significantly alter the treatment landscape for Alzheimer’s disease and potentially other neurodegenerative conditions.

item.title: 6 common foods that can shorten lifespan - The Times of India
item.description:
6 Common Foods That Can Shorten Lifespan

Publication Date: N/A

Source: N/A

The foods we eat daily have a major role in shaping our health. Poor dietary choices can increase the risk of chronic illnesses and even shorten our lifespan.

  • Processed Meats: Linked to cancer and heart disease due to preservatives like nitrates.
  • Sugary Drinks: Major contributors to weight gain and diseases, responsible for over 184,000 deaths annually.
  • Refined Grains: Stripped of nutrients, leading to blood sugar spikes and obesity risk.
  • Fried Foods: Raise bad cholesterol levels, linked to higher risk of early death.
  • Packaged Snacks: High in unhealthy additives and sodium, increasing stroke risk.
  • Artificial Sweeteners: May disrupt gut health and increase cravings for sugar.
Research shows that regular consumption of fried foods is linked to a higher risk of early death, particularly in women.

Choosing healthier alternatives can help improve long-term health and longevity.

item.title: Hate your body fat? Study shows unique fat type that actually helps burn calories - Hindustan Times
item.description:
Hate your body fat? Study shows unique fat type that actually helps burn calories

Date: Jan 17, 2025

Source: Hindustan Times

This article discusses a study from Rutgers University that identifies a type of body fat known as brown fat, which actually assists in burning calories and improving exercise performance.

  • Brown fat is contrasted with regular fat, which typically stores energy.
  • The study suggests that brown fat can enhance physical activity levels and has potential benefits for combating obesity and other age-related health issues.
  • In experiments, modified brown fat was transplanted into mice, dramatically improving their exercise performance in a short period.
  • Brown fat is rich in mitochondria and is essential for thermoregulation in babies.
“These findings are remarkable as they suggest that brown fat’s unique properties could be leveraged to combat age-related health challenges such as obesity, diabetes, and cardiovascular diseases.”

This study sheds light on the positive aspects of a fat type often perceived negatively, pointing towards innovative therapeutic possibilities in health and fitness.

item.title: Obese children diagnosed with cancer may face higher risk of death - Euronews
item.description:
Obese Children Diagnosed with Cancer May Face Higher Risk of Death

Publication Date: N/A Source: N/A

Children with obesity who are diagnosed with cancer may have poorer health outcomes, including a higher risk of death, according to a new study. Researchers analyzed the data of over 11,000 cancer patients aged between 2 and 19.

  • 10.5% of the patients were obese at diagnosis.
  • Conditions studied included leukaemia, lymphoma, and other tumours.
  • Obese children had a 16% increased risk of relapse and a 29% increased risk of death after adjusting for various factors.
  • The impact was particularly strong for patients with acute lymphoblastic leukaemia and brain tumours.
  • The study highlights the negative impact of obesity and suggests a need for different strategies to mitigate risks.
“Our study highlights the negative impact of obesity among all types of childhood cancers.” - Thai Hoa Tran

The study indicates urgent action is needed to address childhood obesity to prevent significant health consequences.

item.title: Study Links Exposure To Pollution Before Pregnancy With Childhood Obesity - Bizz Buzz
item.description:
Study Links Exposure To Pollution Before Pregnancy With Childhood Obesity

Date: Thursday

Source: Environmental Research

This study reveals that increased exposure to air pollution before conception may elevate childhood obesity risk for up to two years post-birth.

  • The research highlights the importance of the three months prior to conception.
  • Conducted with 5,834 mother-child pairs from Shanghai.
  • Findings show significant associations between pollution exposure and increased BMI in children.
  • A 0.078 increase in BMIZ is linked to PM2.5 exposure; a 0.093 kg/m2 increase in BMI is linked to PM10.
  • The risk of obesity may begin even before pregnancy due to widespread air pollution.
“These findings imply that the three months before conception are important, and that people who plan to bear children should consider taking measures to lower their air pollution exposure to reduce their children’s risk for obesity.” - Jiawen Liao

This study underscores the critical need for prospective parents to mitigate environmental risks that could impact child health.

item.title: Nutritional support could prevent tuberculosis deaths, cases in India by 2035: Lancet study - CNBCTV18
item.description:
Nutritional Support Could Prevent TB Deaths and Cases in India by 2035: Lancet Study

Publication Date: Not specified in the article.

Source: The Lancet Global Health

This study indicates that providing nutritional support to half of the households undergoing tuberculosis (TB) treatment in India may significantly reduce TB deaths and cases by 2035.

  • Approximately 4.5% of TB-related deaths might be prevented.
  • About 2.2% of TB disease episodes could be averted.
  • Estimates suggest that more than 360,000 deaths and over 880,000 TB cases could be averted.
  • The intervention may cost about USD 1,349 million but offers a potential economic benefit of USD 167 per disability-adjusted life-year averted.
  • An earlier study by the same research team revealed a drop in TB incidence by 39-48% through nutritional support for household contacts of TB patients.
  • The findings suggest a greater focus on states with high levels of undernutrition could enhance effectiveness.
“We found that if India can deliver a nutritional intervention to 50% of households in which individuals are receiving tuberculosis treatment, nearly 900,000 episodes of tuberculosis would be averted, and nearly 400,000 deaths, at a cost of USD 167 per disability-adjusted life-year averted,” the authors wrote.

In conclusion, nutritional support is a cost-effective approach likely to yield substantial health and economic benefits in combating tuberculosis in India.

item.title: Cervical cancer - The Hindu
item.description:
Cervical Cancer Awareness Month: Importance of HPV Vaccination in India

Date & Source: January 17, 2025, The Hindu

January is Cervical Cancer Awareness Month, and doctors are urging women to get screened for this disease. Cervical cancer, primarily caused by the Human Papillomavirus (HPV), remains a significant health concern for women in India.

  • HPV is responsible for 99.7% of cervical cancers globally.
  • India currently offers HPV vaccines through prescription from private practitioners.
  • The National Technical Advisory Group for Immunisation (NTAGI) recommends inclusion of HPV vaccines in the national immunisation program.
  • Cervical cancer is the third most common cancer among Indian women, with a significant mortality rate.
  • Cost and cultural perceptions obstruct HPV vaccine uptake.
“Every two minutes, a woman dies from cervical cancer...” - WHO Director-General, Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus

In conclusion, increasing awareness and access to HPV vaccination can lead to a substantial decrease in cervical cancer incidence and mortality in India.

item.title: Long overdue, short-term regimen for TB set to be a game changer - The Hindu
item.description:
Long overdue, short-term regimen for TB set to be a game changer

Date: January 17, 2025 Source: The Hindu

The introduction of a new short-term regimen for multidrug resistant tuberculosis (MDR-TB) offers hope for patients, potentially transforming treatment protocols and improving adherence.

  • MDR-TB is a serious illness, with high risks of death, particularly in India where 27% of global cases were reported.
  • Traditional treatment regimens for DR-TB were lengthy and involved toxic side effects.
  • New regimens like BPaL can shorten treatment duration to 6 months and are designed to be less toxic.
  • Continuous monitoring and evaluation of drug effectiveness is essential to prevent resistance.
  • Health system preparedness and training for healthcare professionals are crucial for successful implementation.
“Shorter regimens are likely to be more expensive for the program. However, continuing inexpensive but toxic regimens would be myopic.”

In conclusion, while the new treatment regimens for TB are a significant advancement, a comprehensive approach addressing systemic issues and social determinants is necessary for long-term success.

item.title: Making cancer care more affordable in India - Hindustan Times
item.description:
Making Cancer Care More Affordable in India

Date: Jan 17, 2025
Source: Hindustan Times

The article discusses the progress made in cancer care in India with efforts aimed at improving accessibility and affordability. It emphasizes the need for further measures to enhance the quality of care and reduce costs, especially in light of the upcoming Union Budget 2025.

  • Government has exempted three cancer medicines from customs duty in the last budget.
  • The upcoming Union Budget presents an opportunity to invest in infrastructure and local manufacturing of medicines.
  • Ayushman Bharat scheme aims to provide health coverage, but gaps in public awareness about health insurance persist.
  • The economic impact of cancer treatment costs approximately ₹75,000 crore annually.
  • High import duties on medical equipment contribute to the high costs of cancer care.
  • Local manufacturing and reducing profit margins on medicines are necessary for affordable treatment.
  • Prevention and quality primary health care are crucial for addressing cancer effectively.
Cancer treatment has become increasingly complex, requiring specialized treatments and doctors, raising costs significantly.

In conclusion, addressing the affordability of cancer care in India requires a holistic approach, including policy changes, investment in infrastructure, and greater public awareness.

item.title: Cracking the code of the extracellular matrix - The Transmitter: Neuroscience News and Perspectives
item.description:
Cracking the code of the extracellular matrix

Publication Date: October 2023
Source: Unknown

This article explores the significant role of the extracellular matrix (ECM) in brain function, detailing how ECM proteins influence neuronal plasticity, learning, and their potential implications for neurodegenerative diseases.

  • The discovery that ECM digestion can restore visual cortex plasticity after the critical period.
  • Up to 20% of the brain consists of ECM, which plays various roles in synaptic function and myelin formation.
  • ECM proteins could be crucial for what makes human brains unique and healthy.
  • Recent studies tie ECM proteins to youthfulness in brain biomarkers and their dysregulation in Alzheimer's disease.
  • The ECM field in neuroscience has been underexplored despite its importance.
  • Challenges remain with scientific blind spots and technical limitations in studying ECM proteins.
  • Advances in proteomics and a shift in thinking are necessary to fully understand the ECM and its implications for brain research.
“If the matrix involves the same degree of complexity and precision, the potential payoff for our understanding of brain plasticity and brain diseases could be immense.”

Overall, the article emphasizes the need for collaboration in neuroscience to address the complexities of the ECM and its role in brain function.

item.title: Fatality ratio of up to 88%, 8 suspected cases: WHO, Tanzania disagree over Marburg virus outbreak - Mathrubhumi English
item.description:
Fatality ratio of up to 88%, 8 suspected cases: WHO, Tanzania disagree over Marburg virus outbreak

Publication Date: January 15, 2025 Source: Mathrubhumi

The World Health Organisation (WHO) reports of eight suspected Marburg virus-related deaths in northern Tanzania, while local authorities refute these claims, stating no positive tests. This divergence has raised concerns about disease surveillance and public health responses.

  • WHO reports 9 suspected Marburg cases, with 8 deaths.
  • Tanzanian Health Minister denies any confirmed cases.
  • Immediate investigation and testing by Tanzanian health officials showed no positive results for Marburg.
  • Marburg virus is highly contagious and fatal in up to 88% of cases without treatment.
  • WHO considers the outbreak risk high nationally and regionally, but low globally.
  • Previous outbreaks have seen significant mortality rates, with health workers among the most affected.
“We would expect further cases in the coming days as disease surveillance improves.” - Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus, WHO Chief
“As of 15th January 2025, laboratory results for all suspected individuals were negative for the Marburg virus.” - Jenista Mhagama, Tanzania's Health Minister

This incident underscores the challenges in managing emerging infectious diseases and the importance of accurate reporting and communication between agencies and governments.

item.title: A golden age of cancer treatment? – podcast - The Guardian
item.description:
A Golden Age of Cancer Treatment? – Podcast

Publication Date: Not specified Source: The Guardian

This article discusses advances in cancer treatment that have transformed options available for patients, including personalized treatments and new technologies, while acknowledging ongoing challenges.

  • Historically, cancer treatment options were limited to surgery, radiation, and chemotherapy.
  • Billions of dollars have been invested in new cancer treatment technologies, including immunotherapy and artificial intelligence.
  • Despite advancements, challenges remain in the distribution of these new technologies to patients globally.
  • The article highlights personal stories, such as that of Abbie Halls, who participated in a successful clinical trial.
“How to distribute these expensive new technologies to everyone who needs them?”

The advancements in cancer treatment are promising, but attention is needed to ensure equitable access to these innovative therapies.

item.title: How vitamin B12 deficiency can affect adults dangerously - The Times of India
item.description:
How Vitamin B12 Deficiency Can Dangerously Affect Adults

Publication Date: N/A Source: Times of India

Vitamin B12 deficiency is a significant health concern that can lead to serious consequences for adults, impacting neurological function and overall health.

  • Vitamin B12 is crucial for proper nerve function and the production of DNA and red blood cells.
  • Deficiency can result in symptoms such as fatigue, weakness, constipation, and cognitive disturbances.
  • Long-term deficiency can lead to irreversible neurological damage if left untreated.
  • Older adults and individuals with certain dietary restrictions are at higher risk.
"Vitamin B12 is vital for maintaining health, and its deficiency can dangerously impair bodily functions."

Addressing vitamin B12 deficiency is essential for preventing serious health risks, making awareness and dietary adjustments crucial.

item.title: Diabetics, here’s what happens to the body if you skip breakfast - The Indian Express
item.description:
Diabetics, here’s what happens to the body if you skip breakfast

Publication Date: January 17, 2025

Source: Indian Express

For those with diabetes, breakfast is critical for maintaining balanced blood sugar levels and supporting overall health. Skipping breakfast can lead to both physiological and psychological complications.

  • Skipping breakfast can lead to elevated blood sugar levels later in the day.
  • It can worsen insulin resistance.
  • Missing this essential meal increases the risk of long-term health complications.
  • Breakfast provides vital nutrients necessary for metabolic balance.
  • It can lead to psychological effects such as mood swings and increased hunger.

Healthy breakfast tips for diabetics

Individuals with diabetes should prioritize a well-balanced breakfast, including low glycaemic index carbohydrates, lean proteins, healthy fats, and fibre-rich foods.

“To optimise blood sugar control, individuals with diabetes should prioritize a well-balanced breakfast,” said Kanikka Malhotra, consultant dietician and diabetes educator.

item.title: Coffee in the morning is best for heart health, says study: Can this routine work for you? - The Indian Express
item.description:
Coffee in the morning is best for heart health, says study: Can this routine work for you?

Date: January 17, 2025 Source: Indian Express

The study suggests that drinking coffee in the morning may lead to lower risks of cardiovascular diseases compared to consuming it throughout the day.

  • Morning coffee drinkers are 31% less likely to die from cardiovascular disease.
  • The study involved 40,725 adults in the US.
  • Dr. Komal Shah highlights the importance of sleep quality and its relation to coffee consumption timing.
  • Overconsumption of caffeine can lead to heightened blood pressure and poor sleep quality.
  • Moderate coffee consumption under 300 mg per day is recommended.
“These findings suggest that morning coffee consumption may have beneficial effects on cardiovascular health at the population level.” - Study conclusion

Overall, the study advocates for morning coffee as a healthier routine that could protect against heart-related issues, emphasizing moderation and timing in consumption.
